intro: Raphanistrocarpus boivinii, commonly known as the Boivin's turnip. It is a rare and little-known plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family, native to the island of Réunion in the Indian Ocean. The plant is characterized by its short, upright growth habit and small, white flowers that bloom in clusters. Its leaves are lobed and have a slightly hairy texture, while its root system is fibrous and not particularly enlarged. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
